thread.title: Hockey: Men's Black Sticks miss chance to secure Rio spot
thread.title_full: Hockey: Men's Black Sticks miss chance to secure Rio spot

title: Hockey: Men's Black Sticks miss chance to secure Rio spot
text:
Hockey 
The men's Black Sticks' dream of automatic Rio Olympics qualification ended in Stratford yesterday. 
A 3-2 loss to world No1 Australia shut the door on their chance of joining the women's team on their own merit in Rio next year. 
A chance remains depending on the outcome of the African qualifying competition on now in South Africa. 
Yesterday, for all that they worked their socks off in the final quarter striving for an equaliser, they realised they had done themselves enormous damage when failing to qualify through the world league semifinal tournament in Buenos Aires in June. 
Defeats to lower-ranked Canada and Spain were costly. They were left battling a country they had beaten once in seven outings since the London Olympics three years ago. 
The outcome meant Ireland, ranked 14th (seven spots lower than New Zealand), qualify for their first Olympic tournament since 1908. 
Australian captain Mark Knowles paid tribute to New Zealand after his team had effectively rubbished the whispers, largely from Europe, that they would go soft on their rivals. 
"These are guys we've grown up playing against, and this isn't the way you'd like it to go," a magnanimous Knowles said. 
Australia struck two hammer blows inside the first six minutes, capitalising on a flying start with goals from Glenn Turner and Jamie Dwyer. 
The impressive James Coughlan pulled one back, but when Trent Mitton scored from a sharp angle after New Zealand were denied a penalty corner, it looked a lost cause. 
However the Black Sticks poured forward and had a string of penalty corners in the dying minutes, with Kane Russell scoring from one. 
Coughlan, veteran Ryan Archibald, in probably the final international of an 18-year career, defender Bradley Shaw and Nick Wilson all had their moments. 
"I am gutted," captain Simon Child said. "We were a little slow out of the blocks and Australia's tempo blew us off the park." 
It was double success for Australia yesterday, their world No 2-ranked women beating fourth-ranked New Zealand 2-1 in a penalty shootout after the scores were locked 1-1. 
Petrea Webster put New Zealand ahead early with a brave, diving goal. Seven minutes before halftime Laura Barden equalised. 
New Zealand created several chances, notably to Webster, Stacey Michelsen and Pippa Hayward, while captain Anita Punt was outstanding. 
The penalty shootout went the Aussies' way with Jodie Kenny and Mariah Williams scoring, while Charlotte Harrison was the only successful New Zealander. 
- By David Leggat of the New Zealand Herald
